8GVs9_aixhMf1gIK5JGlUQ.text: When the difference in prices between food courts and restaurants is becoming incredibly small...Really love this place for its quality roasts, rice and noodles! The portion given for the noodles is rather generous (for both the noodles and the meat), and would definitely make a filling meal. They also have a number of interesting sides such as the fried intestines, duck tongue, and other animal parts (organs!!¡) which may take a little courage to try but will not leave you disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore

MLhqwbynSEStzEci6IYaXQ.text: I've been here twice so far and definitely think I'll be the Duchess, if not a frequent regular. I work and live near by, and seriously, this is place is the most "authentic" Cantonese restaurant in the area. It's not too expensive either, another plus.The first time I was here, I had dimsum with my colleagues. A few of them have been here qutie a few times already and highly recommended the BBQ pork pastry. Now, don't get confused! There are 3 different types of BBQ pork on the dimsum menu, but the pastry is the one you should be looking for! Buttery and flakey on the outside with hot-pipping BBQ pork on the inside. The fried shrimp bean curd here is quite nice as well. The typical shuimai, hargow, and coeng fen (my dimsum must-haves) were mediocre for Hong Kong standards but surprisingly good (aka no leftover frostbite) for Singapore standards. Sadly, dimsum is only offered during lunch times. I've also had the congee here, which was quite nice. The price tag seems a bit steep at $7-9++ a bowl, especially when comparing to the hawker center across the street ($3), but hey! you get what you pay for...meaning, there's AC. The congee here isn't too thick or watery and can be personalized to your liking. I selected the Two Treasure option: century egg and sliced fish. Overall, a simple reasonably priced restaurant that I'll stop by whenever I need to get my congee and dimsum fixed on. P.S. Please don't criticize my spelling of shuimai, hargow, and coeng fen--all taken from the dimsum article on Wikipedia :D

photos.caption: Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Glutinous rice--not impressive
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Sliced fish and century egg rice roll
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Sliced Abalone Congee

Sdov92s6s_f6uOcs249d_w.text: Dear Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House,Please accept my heartfelt apologies for the grave error I made in writing a review without first trying your heavenly dim sum!  Your nubile shrimp dumplings were perfectly plump and dimpled and stuffed with succulent prawns blushing pink beneath translucent skins.  Each bite burst with tender flavor.Your fried bean curd skin rolls were fried ethereally crisp with juicy fillings and a mysterious lack of greasiness.  I smothered these darlings in your exquisite, homemade hot sauce.Your chicken and mushroom pastries were extremely decadent, likely made with more butter and cream than I will ever want to know about.  They reminded me of mini Aussie pies and made me smile very widely.If you served dim sum all day long, I will pledge to you my eternal devotion and one extra Yelp star.X,FatsPARTING THOUGHT: Seriously, this is one of the best dim sum meals I've EVER had...can't wait to try more options!

photos.caption: Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Mini egg tarts
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Steamed shrimp rolls
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Pan fried turnip cake

qiW2I8tsIjepzLr20LemXw.text: The food is very good, the venue is super nice and clean and modern. The portions are quite small.The restaurant was about 20% capacity when we dined and there was a lady that pretty much just stood there by our table watching us eat. Talk about awkward.None of the waitstaff spoke English - a bummer for the Chinese-challenged bunch, myself included.Must come back and try the dim sum but for the regular dishes, probably not worth a re-visit as you can find similarly good stuff for half the price and twice the portion not far away.

photos.caption: Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Chicken corn soup, tiny portion for $8.
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Side dish of vegetables of the day, not bad but again, small portions for $10.
Photo of Imperial Treasure Noodle and Congee House - Singapore, Singapore. Dry noodles with beef brisket, quite tasty but very small portions.

4r5pLYQvRGl_GJ78RMEcdg.text: Slightly on the pricey end but can't deny this place has become a regular for me when it comes to dim sum, roast meat, congee and other typical HK dishes. Service is impeccable living up to the Imperial Treasure brand.

Q4w2Nu2BVk0tNShYaaf_iQ.text: solid placecongee was excellentother dishes were quite greasy but it was delicious

AF-QnRUMDYtlRCS0oyTctA.text: For more reviews, please go to thehungrybunnie.blogspot…Little surprise that the food is good and service efficient in this casual arm of the much lauded Imperial Treasure. Reservations are highly recommended. Otherwise be prepared to queue or be turned away.We had:1) Deep-Fried Beancurd Skin Roll ($5.20): crisp and juicy2) Steamed Pork Dumplings ($5.20): bouncy, plump and juicy.3) Steamed Diced Mushroom Dumplings ($4.20): my favourite dim sum item here, delicious in an earthy, chunky and chewy way. 4) Steamed Glutinous Rice ($4): soft, moist, and choc-a-bloc with minced chicken, salted egg yolk and dried shrimp. 5) Steamed Custard Bun ($3.90): oozy and smooth with the most miniscule grainy texture, was a very good rendition indeed. Despite the fact that my heart belongs to the chocolate-laced version at Lei Garden. 6) Century Egg & Lean Meat Congee ($7.20): a comforting bowl of delicate baby-smooth gruel, and loaded with wobbly century egg quarters and pulled pork.

ktCQ2lmOuJOjVbSkAkN05A.text: Cane here for a business lunch. You should get reservations ahead of time if your party is more than 2 people.  The dim sum was amazing. We tried the noodles too which were ok, but not phenomenal. The duck was very good and well worth ordering. I particularly enjoyed the eggplant.
